SENT.plain: Central nervous system (CNS) infarcts were present at autopsy in 10 of 23 alcoholic patients and in 9 of 36 nonalcoholic patients
There were more males than expected in the infarct population and in the alcoholic population
Male subjects comprised the entire population of alcoholics with infarcts
In addition, a history of alcohol abuse was present in every case of cerebral infarction dying before age 75
The incidence of cardiomegaly was increased among the alcoholics
There were no differences between alcoholics and nonalcoholics in the incidence of diagnosed hypertension, moderate-to-severe coronary atherosclerosis, or adult onset diabetes
However, CNS infarction was more likely to occur at an earlier age in alcoholics than in nonalcoholics
Excessive alcohol consumption may be a risk factor in the premature development of cerebrovascular disease in males
